dsls.content1: Match the grid to the program.
dsls.title: Matching

answers.text:
Start with a square  
Put a triangle above the square  
Put a triangle below the square

Start with a square  
Put a triangle right of square  
Put a parallelogram below square  
Put triangle right of parallelogram

Start with a square  
Put a parallelogram above the square  
Put a triangle right of the parallelogram

Start with a square  
Put a triangle below the square  
Put a parallelogram right of the triangle

questions.text: Choose an algorithm for the image provided.

dsls.content1:
Start with a triangle  
Put a square below the triangle  
Put another triangle below the square

questions.text: Which image does _not_ follow this algorithm?

dsls.title: Multiple Choice

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Can you help me catch the naughty pig? Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Can you help me catch the naughty pig? 

Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_1_a: To use a `move forward` block, drag it from the toolbar area out into the workspace and connect it to the `when run` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: This pig is ruffling my feathers. Help me get to him!
Trace the path and lead me to the silly pig. Avoid TNT or feathers will fly!
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
Keep calm and help me find the bad pig. Otherwise I might get angry!

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_6_a: There are two ways to solve this puzzle!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
Get me to the pig!
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: _"The pig is hiding! Can you help me find a way around?"_
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: _"The pig is hiding! Can you help me find a way around?"_

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Sometimes there is more than one way to solve the same problem. Sometimes it's faster to go backwards than it is to go forwards!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Sometimes there is more than one way to solve the same problem. Sometimes it's faster to go backwards than it is to go forwards!

authored_hints.courseC_maze_programming_challenge2_a: _If you send me backwards, be extra careful that I turn the correct way!_
authored_hints.courseC_maze_programming_challenge2_b: The shortest solution use only 5 blocks, but it uses the `repeat` block!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_1_new_a: If you use the block to have me `move forward by 100 pixels`, I will draw a line automatically.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_1_new_b: Having trouble turning the corner? Use the `turn right 90 degrees` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_2_new_a: The artist doesn't seem to be pointing in the correct direction. Can you make them turn first before drawing the line?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
The red hat is 100 pixels tall. Finish drawing a black hat that is 70 pixels shorter. 
(Note: The width of each hat is 50 pixels.)
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
The red hat is 100 pixels tall. Finish drawing a black hat that is 70 pixels shorter. 

_(Note: The width of each hat is 50 pixels.)_

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_3new_a: What is 100-70?  Based on the story problem, that's how tall the hat needs to be!
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_3new_b: The artist doesn't seem to be pointing in the correct direction. Can you make them turn first before drawing the line?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the `jump forward` and `move forward` blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the `jump forward` and `move forward` blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Help me complete the house for this cat.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Help me complete the house for this cat.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_4_a: To finish the house, all we need to do is draw a square!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle.  Hint: all three sides are the same length.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle. Hint: all three sides are the same length.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_6_a: To make those little angles, you have to turn _farther_ each time than you did with the square.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_6_b: Since I'm already facing to the right, it's easiest to start by moving forward, then make left turns to create the triangle.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_6_c: Each side of the triangle is the same length as each side of the square...100 pixels!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Finish this kite
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Finish this kite

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_9_a: This diamond is really just a square on its side

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Finish drawing the last set of windows on the school so that everyone in class can see outside. The sides of each square window pane are 25 pixels long.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Finish drawing the last set of windows on the school so that everyone in class can see outside. 

The sides of each square window pane are 25 pixels long.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_7_a: The easiest way to solve this puzzle is to draw the first square and end with the artist pointing down before starting your second square.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Complete the rooms for each of the animals by splitting the rectangle into 2 equal-sized squares. The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Time to build a barn!

Make the rooms for each animal by splitting the barn into 2 equal-sized squares. 

Hint: The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall.

There are many different ways to solve this puzzle.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_8_a: If you cut 200 in half, how many pixels wide does each square need to be?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Free-play! Draw anything you'd like.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Free-play! Draw anything you'd like.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Assessment: Finish drawing the last tooth. It is 25 pixels wide and 25 pixels tall.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: **Assessment:** Finish drawing the last tooth. It is 25 pixels wide and 25 pixels tall.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Draw rooms for each of the animals. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun. The shortest possible solution is 6 blocks, but use as many as you like!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Draw rooms for each of the animals. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun!

You can put commands inside `repeat` block to loop them over and over. Try it!

questions.text: How would you simplify this sequence with loops?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Can you get me to the pig using 5 of the same kind of blocks?
Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Suddenly, a magical block appears!  With the `repeat` block, you can loop code over and over.

Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Get me to the pig! You can only use one move forward block this time
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Get me to the pig! You can only use one `move forward` block this time

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Can you figure out the fastest way to get me to the pig?
Loops even work with more than one block inside!  Can you loop this sequence to get the zombie to the sunflower?

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_16_a: If the pattern is hard to see, try coding it all out first and see what things repeat over and over before you put the loops in.
authored_hints.2-3_Maze_16_b:
To put lots of blocks inside a `repeat` loop, just drag a loop out into the workspace, then drag all of the blocks from the starting program inside of it.  

Connect it all back to the `when run` block and you're good to go!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Use what you learned to get me to the sunflower!

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_17_a: If the pattern is hard to see, try coding it all out first and see what things repeat over and over before you put the loops in.
authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_17_b: Did the starting code get deleted?  Click `start over` to get it back!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!  

Try using one `repeat` loop inside of another to cut down on the amount of code you need.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!  

Try using one `repeat` loop inside of another to cut down on the amount of code you need.

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_18_a: If the pattern is hard to see, try coding it all out first and see what things repeat over and over before you put the loops in.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
Let's take this to another level! 
Use loops to get me to the sunflower with the fewest loops possible.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Let's take this to another level! 

Use loops to get me to the sunflower with the fewest loops possible.

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_19_a: If you are stuck, try writing out the code without loops first and looking for patterns.
authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_19_b: Putting one repeat loop inside of another can help decrease the number of blocks used.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Get me to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible!

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_20_a: Look for a stair-step pattern in this maze to find where a loop can be used.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!

authored_hints.2-3_Maze_Loops_21_a: If you are having trouble finding the stair-step pattern, try covering the blocked paths with your finger.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Assessment:  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: **Assessment:**  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Now Scrat wants to try using loops to find his acorn!

authored_hints.courseC_maze_loops_challenge1_a: Think about this path as being three different pieces. Each one has a pattern you can repeat.
authored_hints.courseC_maze_loops_challenge1_b: In between each `repeat` block, you will need to `turn left` or `turn right` to get ready Scrat for the next pattern.
authored_hints.courseC_maze_loops_challenge1_c:
If you make it this far, you just need to `turn left` then `move forward` a few times. Don't give up!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
_"Let's hunt for treasure - using loops!"_

Help the collector by debugging this code. Get all of the treasure!

authored_hints.courseC_maze_loops_challenge2_a: The original code would work great - if there was only one piece of treasure in each pile!
authored_hints.courseC_maze_loops_challenge2_b: Use loops so you don't run out of `collect` blocks!

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_4_a:
There are 360 degrees in a circle! 

That's how many times you need to repeat this code (turning 1 degree at a time) before the circle is done!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Give the stop sign a border by making an octagon with 100 pixels sides.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Give the stop sign a border by making an octagon with 100 pixels sides.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_11_a: Having trouble with the angles? You need to go 360 degrees in 8 turns.  What is 360/8?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
Create a circle to finish the eyeball!

If the artist turns 1 degree with each loop, how many times do you need to repeat the code to draw a circle? 180? 360? 500?
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Create a circle to finish the eyeball! 

If the artist turns 1 degree with each loop, how many times do you need to repeat the code to draw a circle?

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_12_a: There are 360 degrees in a circle, so if the artist turns 1 degree each time through the loop, he'll need to go through 360 times.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Draw a simple V (where both sides are 50 pixels) to complete the arrow.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Draw a simple V (where both sides are 50 pixels) to complete the arrow.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_9_a: The artist needs to turn 45 degrees to the right before he starts drawing.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_9_b: This V is really just half of a square.  What would the code be to draw half of a square?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Time to make something snazzy! 

Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_11_a:
Remember that the code from the last puzzle was:

[blockly block][0]
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_11_b: Your new turn should go at the **end** of the code inside the loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Draw a diamond with sides of 100 pixels.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Draw a diamond with sides of 100 pixels.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist Loops_New_12_a: Before starting the diamond, the artist needs to turn left by 60 degrees to get on the right path.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist Loops_New_12_b: After the artist goes forward 100 pixels, he will need to turn right 120 degrees to make the sharp corner.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist Loops_New_12_c: The artist will need to turn right only 60 degrees to create a wide corner.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
We are going to start you with some code (in grey) to make one diamond. 

Loop the grey code to create a fun pattern!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
We are going to start you with some code (in grey) to make one diamond. 

Loop the grey code to create a fun pattern!

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_13_a:
At the end of each diamond, the artist is already facing the right direction to start the next one.  

Because of this, we don't need to add an extra `turn left by` block before we start again.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_13_b:
To make each diamond, the artist needs to:   

-   move
-   turn right 120 degrees
-   move
-   turn right 60 degrees  

Then do it all again!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Play around with the code for the diamond and see what other patterns you can make. Try changing how many degrees you turn and how many times you loop.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Play around with the code for the diamond and see what other patterns you can make. 

Try changing how many degrees you turn and how many times you loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Now, draw anything you like!

questions.text: Which blocks collect all of the nectar?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Collect all of the corn.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Collect all of the corn.

authored_hints.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge1_a: Don't even think about try about trying this without loops!
authored_hints.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge1_b: You can repeat `move forward` and `pick corn` as many times as you need to, then `turn right` at each corner.
authored_hints.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge1_c:
The best way to collect the first four corn uses a `repeat` block inside of another `repeat` block. You can use this pattern for the rest of the puzzle too!

[blockly block][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Collect all of the lettuce. Avoid the trees and fields!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Collect all of the lettuce. Avoid the trees and fields!

authored_hints.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge2_a: One way to solve this looks like a zig-zag. Another way looks like a spiral! There are lots of different solutions to a puzzle like this. Be persistent!
authored_hints.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge2_b: You can repeat `move forward` and `pick lettuce` as many times as you need to, then turn at each corner.
authored_hints.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge2_c:

dsls.teacher_markdown:
## Teachers:

Students might be operating off of a misconception, and this is a great place to tease that out.  If students think that there is *no* correct answer, then they probably have a misunderstanding around conditionals.

Here is a video that helps explain what is going on in this question:

https://youtu.be/TbUaEnAYPjI
dsls.title: Multiple Choice

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
I'm a hungry bee! 
Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
I'm a hungry bee! 

Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.

authored_hints.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_3_a: The code will be shortest if you use a loop each time you move forward, another loop to gather nectar, and another one to make honey.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions:
Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. 
You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
These magic purple flowers change!

Each time you try the puzzle, purple flowers can have either 1 nectar or none at all...but you won't know the number until you run the code! 

Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. 
You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.

callouts.Bee_Cond_5_1a: Purple flowers can have either 1 or 0 nectar...but you won't know until you run the code!

Collect all the nectar from each flower.

Help me fly around the yard and collect nectar only from the flowers that have some.

authored_hints.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_14_a: Having a hard time figuring out how to get the blocks down?  Try treating the red flower exactly the same as a purple flower!
authored_hints.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_14_b: If the red flower were purple, could you figure out how to use an extra `repeat` loop to cut down on code?
authored_hints.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_14_c:
Try breaking this up into two separate chunks:

[][0]

1.  Gather nectar 3 times
    -   Move forward 5 times
    -   Check to see if nectar, if so: get it
    -   Turn left

2.  Make honey
    -   Move forward one time
    -   Make two honey

This stair step pattern should look familiar.

authored_hints.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_15_a: Remember: Purple flowers only have either 0 or 1 nectar and they can change each time you run the program.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Assessment: Collect all of the nectar. Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
**Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar.\
Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Collect all of the nectar and make all the honey. You can collect all of the nectar in one flower by using the `while nectar > 0` loop.

authored_hints.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_b:
Just like the `if at flower` blocks, the code inside a `while nectar > 0` will only run if the bee is at a flower. The main differences is that the code inside will run repetitively until there is no nectar left.  Try this pattern:

[blockly block][0]

callouts.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge2_1: Use this loop to collect all of the nectar (or honey) from one flower (or honeycomb).

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions: Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey. You can only collect nectar from flowers and make honey from honeycombs. Check any space to see if there is a flower or honeycomb.

authored_hints.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_a:
Can you find a path that reaches every flower and honeycomb without hitting any trees? The best path is a spiral.

**You can solve this without ever turning left.**
authored_hints.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_b: In this puzzle, each space could have a flower, a honey comb, or nothing.  That means you can repeat your `if/else` conditional at each square.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Attach a block to the "when click" block, then press "Run". Click or tap the screen to move Flappy to the target.
Now we've added some ground.  Attach a block to the "when hit the ground" block.  Your code needs to 'END GAME' when Flappy crashes.
The "when run" block allows you to run code when your game starts.  Try setting the level speed and flapping to the target.

Flappy will fly through obstacles unless you write code to make him crash. Attach a block to the "when hit an obstacle" block. Your code needs to 'END GAME' when Flappy crashes into the first set of pipes.
Let's add a scoreboard, and count points when Flappy makes it past obstacles. Add to the "when pass an obstacle" block, and then score a point by flying Flappy through the first set of pipes.
See if you can still score a point after making Flappy flap either a smaller or larger amount.
Next, try changing the scene by attaching another block to the "when run" block.
You can set visuals anytime, not just when the game starts. Try setting a RANDOM scene when other events happen, for example, when passing an obstacle.
To mix things up, when hitting an obstacle, instead of ending the game try setting the score back to 0.
Create your own Flappy game. You can change all the visuals and all the rules, even the gravity. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?

-   Both shapes have **50 pixel sides.**
-   The _octagons_ are made with **45 degree** turns.
-   The _triangles_ are made with **120 degree** turns.

authored_hints.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge1_a: Start by making a nested loop to create four octagons. Turn 45 degrees to make the octagon. Jump, then turn 90 degrees after each one.
authored_hints.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge1_b: Add code to draw a triangle inside of your nested loop. Use 120 degree turns for your triangle.
authored_hints.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge1_c:
Use a nested loop:

-   Repeat 8 times
    -   draw an octagon
    -   draw a triangle
    -   jump forward 50 pixels
    -   turn right by 90 degrees

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.short_instructions: Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.long_instructions:
Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?

-   The first inner loop should make an octagon.
-   The second inner loop should make a hexagon.
-   The third inner loop should make a square.

authored_hints.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge2_a: To draw a regular octagon, the artist needs to turn 45 degrees 8 times.
authored_hints.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge2_b: To draw a square, the artist needs to turn 90 degrees 4 times.
